metadata.subject: chemistry
metadata.dotPoint: Trends in physical properties within and between homologous series (boiling point and melting point, viscosity), with reference to structure and bonding

dispersion_forces.name: Dispersion Forces
dispersion_forces.formula: Present in all molecules; strength increases with molar mass and surface area
dispersion_forces.correct: Dispersion forces exist between ALL molecules and increase in strength with larger molar mass and greater surface area of contact between molecules.

only in non-polar molecules.error: Dispersion forces exist in ALL molecules, not just non-polar ones.
only in non-polar molecules.fix: Dispersion forces arise from temporary dipoles caused by electron movement. All molecules have electrons, so all molecules have dispersion forces.
only in non-polar molecules.action: Remember: dispersion = universal. Polar molecules have dispersion PLUS other forces.

only in polar molecules.error: Reversed. Dispersion forces are the ONLY force in non-polar molecules, but they exist in polar molecules too.
only in polar molecules.fix: Non-polar molecules: dispersion only. Polar molecules: dispersion + dipole-dipole (or hydrogen bonding).
only in polar molecules.action: List forces for methane (dispersion only) vs methanol (dispersion + H-bonding).

decrease with molar mass.error: Opposite relationship. Larger molecules have STRONGER dispersion forces.
decrease with molar mass.fix: More electrons = more polarisable = stronger temporary dipoles = stronger dispersion forces.
decrease with molar mass.action: Compare boiling points: methane (-162°C) vs octane (126°C). Larger = higher b.p. = stronger forces.

persistent.gap: You don't understand dispersion forces act in all molecules and depend on size.
persistent.action: Draw electron clouds for small and large molecules. More electrons = more dispersion force potential.

hydrogen_bonding.name: Hydrogen Bonding
hydrogen_bonding.formula: H bonded to F, N, or O interacting with lone pair on F, N, or O
hydrogen_bonding.correct: Hydrogen bonding occurs when H is bonded to F, N, or O and interacts with a lone pair on another F, N, or O atom. It is stronger than dipole-dipole interactions.

occurs in all molecules with hydrogen.error: H must be bonded to F, N, or O specifically, not just any atom.
occurs in all molecules with hydrogen.fix: Only F, N, O are electronegative enough to create the strong δ+ on H needed for hydrogen bonding.
occurs in all molecules with hydrogen.action: Alkanes have lots of H atoms but no hydrogen bonding. Why? H is bonded to C, not F/N/O.

weaker than dispersion forces.error: Hydrogen bonding is typically STRONGER than dispersion forces for similar-sized molecules.
weaker than dispersion forces.fix: For molecules of similar size: H-bonding > dipole-dipole > dispersion only.
weaker than dispersion forces.action: Compare ethanol (b.p. 78°C) vs propane (similar mass, b.p. -42°C). H-bonding makes huge difference.

only occurs within a single molecule.error: Hydrogen bonding is an INTER-molecular force, between different molecules.
only occurs within a single molecule.fix: Inter = between molecules. Intra = within one molecule. We're discussing intermolecular forces.
only occurs within a single molecule.action: Picture two water molecules. The H-bond forms BETWEEN them, not inside either one.

persistent.gap: You're confusing when hydrogen bonding can occur or its relative strength.
persistent.action: Make a checklist: (1) H bonded to F, N, or O? (2) Lone pair on F, N, or O nearby? Both yes = H-bond.

dipole_dipole.name: Dipole-Dipole Interactions
dipole_dipole.formula: Between polar molecules; δ+ attracts δ−
dipole_dipole.correct: Dipole-dipole interactions occur between polar molecules where the δ+ region of one molecule attracts the δ− region of another.

same as hydrogen bonding.error: Hydrogen bonding is a SPECIAL TYPE of dipole-dipole interaction, but they're not identical.
same as hydrogen bonding.fix: H-bonding is stronger because H bonded to F/N/O creates an especially strong δ+. General dipole-dipole is weaker.
same as hydrogen bonding.action: Aldehydes have dipole-dipole but not H-bonding. Alcohols have H-bonding. Different strength.

occurs in non-polar molecules.error: Dipole-dipole requires permanent dipoles, which only polar molecules have.
occurs in non-polar molecules.fix: Non-polar molecules (like alkanes, symmetric molecules) have no permanent dipole, so no dipole-dipole interaction.
occurs in non-polar molecules.action: Check: does the molecule have a net dipole? If no, then only dispersion forces.

strongest intermolecular force.error: Hydrogen bonding is stronger than general dipole-dipole interactions.
strongest intermolecular force.fix: Ranking: hydrogen bonding > dipole-dipole > dispersion only (for similar-sized molecules).
strongest intermolecular force.action: Compare similar-sized molecules: ethanol (H-bonding, b.p. 78°C) vs propanal (dipole-dipole, b.p. 49°C).

persistent.gap: You're confusing dipole-dipole interactions with hydrogen bonding or other forces.
persistent.action: Identify the functional group: -OH, -NH2, -COOH = H-bonding. -CHO, C=O, -Cl = dipole-dipole. Alkane = dispersion only.

homologous_series_definition.name: Homologous Series Definition
homologous_series_definition.formula: Same functional group, differ by CH₂, similar chemical properties
homologous_series_definition.correct: A homologous series is a family of compounds with the same functional group, where each member differs by CH₂, showing similar chemical properties and gradual trends in physical properties.

molecules with the same molar mass.error: That describes isomers, not a homologous series.
molecules with the same molar mass.fix: Homologous series members have DIFFERENT molar masses (differ by 14 g/mol per CH₂).
molecules with the same molar mass.action: Methanol (32 g/mol), ethanol (46 g/mol), propan-1-ol (60 g/mol) = homologous series with different masses.

molecules with different functional grou.error: Opposite. Homologous series members have the SAME functional group.
molecules with different functional grou.fix: All alcohols have -OH. All carboxylic acids have -COOH. Same functional group = same series.
molecules with different functional grou.action: Ethanol and ethanoic acid have different functional groups, so different homologous series.

structural isomers.error: Isomers have the same molecular formula. Homologous series members have different formulas.
structural isomers.fix: Isomers: same atoms, different arrangement. Homologous series: same functional group, different carbon chain length.
structural isomers.action: Propan-1-ol and propan-2-ol are isomers. Propan-1-ol and butan-1-ol are in same homologous series.

persistent.gap: You're confusing homologous series with isomers or other groupings.
persistent.action: Write out 5 members of the alkanol series. Note: same -OH group, each differs by CH₂.

boiling_point_molar_mass.name: Boiling Point vs Molar Mass
boiling_point_molar_mass.formula: Higher molar mass → stronger dispersion forces → higher boiling point
boiling_point_molar_mass.correct: Within a homologous series, boiling point increases with molar mass because larger molecules have stronger dispersion forces requiring more energy to overcome.

boiling point decreases with molar mass.error: Opposite relationship. Larger molecules have HIGHER boiling points.
boiling point decreases with molar mass.fix: Larger molecules = more electrons = stronger dispersion forces = more energy needed to vaporise = higher b.p.
boiling point decreases with molar mass.action: Look at alkane b.p.: methane -162°C, ethane -89°C, propane -42°C, butane 0°C. Increases with size.

molar mass has no effect on boiling poin.error: Molar mass strongly affects boiling point within a homologous series.
molar mass has no effect on boiling poin.fix: Within same series, molar mass is the main variable. Functional group (and thus force type) is constant.
molar mass has no effect on boiling poin.action: Plot b.p. vs molar mass for alkanes. Clear upward trend.

only affects non-polar molecules.error: Molar mass affects boiling point in ALL homologous series, polar and non-polar.
only affects non-polar molecules.fix: In any series, larger molecules have more dispersion forces. This adds to whatever other forces exist.
only affects non-polar molecules.action: Alcohols: methanol 65°C, ethanol 78°C, propan-1-ol 97°C. Same trend despite H-bonding.

persistent.gap: You don't understand why larger molecules have higher boiling points.
persistent.action: Compare dispersion force diagrams: small molecule (few points of contact) vs large molecule (many contact points).

boiling_point_branching.name: Boiling Point and Branching
boiling_point_branching.formula: More branching → less surface area → weaker dispersion forces → lower boiling point
boiling_point_branching.correct: Branched isomers have lower boiling points than straight-chain isomers because branching reduces surface area for intermolecular contact, weakening dispersion forces.

branching increases boiling point.fix: Branched molecules are more spherical, with less surface area touching neighbouring molecules.
branching increases boiling point.action: Compare pentane (36°C) vs 2,2-dimethylpropane (10°C). Same formula, but branched has lower b.p.

branching has no effect.fix: Same molecular formula but different shapes = different surface areas = different dispersion forces.
branching has no effect.action: Draw pentane (long chain) vs neopentane (spherical). Which has more surface contact? That one has higher b.p.

branching only affects polar molecules.error: Branching affects ALL molecules by changing surface area for dispersion forces.
branching only affects polar molecules.fix: Even non-polar alkanes show this effect clearly. It's about surface area, not polarity.
branching only affects polar molecules.action: Alkanes are non-polar but show clear branching effects. Surface area matters for dispersion.

persistent.gap: You don't understand how molecular shape affects intermolecular forces.
persistent.action: Build molecular models: straight chain vs branched. Compare surface areas available for contact.

boiling_point_functional_group.name: Boiling Point and Functional Group
boiling_point_functional_group.formula: H-bonding > dipole-dipole > dispersion only (for similar molar mass)
boiling_point_functional_group.correct: For molecules of similar molar mass, those capable of hydrogen bonding have highest boiling points, followed by dipole-dipole, then dispersion only.

all functional groups give same boiling.error: Different functional groups give different intermolecular forces and thus different boiling points.
all functional groups give same boiling.fix: Compare similar mass: butane (-0.5°C, dispersion) vs propanal (49°C, dipole-dipole) vs propan-1-ol (97°C, H-bonding).
all functional groups give same boiling.action: Identify the forces each functional group can form. More force types = higher b.p.

dispersion only gives highest boiling po.error: Dispersion only gives LOWEST boiling point for similar molar mass.
dispersion only gives highest boiling po.fix: H-bonding > dipole-dipole > dispersion only. More/stronger forces = higher b.p.
dispersion only gives highest boiling po.action: Alkanes (dispersion only) have much lower b.p. than same-mass alcohols (H-bonding).

functional group matters more than molar.error: Both matter. Within same series, molar mass dominates. Between series, functional group matters.
functional group matters more than molar.fix: A large alkane can have higher b.p. than small alcohol. Both factors are important.
functional group matters more than molar.action: Compare octane (b.p. 126°C, large, dispersion) vs methanol (b.p. 65°C, small, H-bonding).

persistent.gap: You're not considering how functional groups determine intermolecular force types.
persistent.action: Make a table: functional group → force types → relative b.p. for same-size molecules.

melting_point_trend.name: Melting Point Trends
melting_point_trend.formula: Similar to boiling point; stronger IMF → higher melting point
melting_point_trend.correct: Melting point generally increases with molar mass within a homologous series, as stronger intermolecular forces are harder to disrupt from the solid lattice.

opposite to boiling point trends.error: Melting and boiling point trends are generally SIMILAR, not opposite.
opposite to boiling point trends.fix: Both depend on intermolecular forces. Stronger forces = harder to disrupt solid OR liquid = higher m.p. AND b.p.
opposite to boiling point trends.action: Compare trends: both m.p. and b.p. increase with molar mass in alkanes.

unrelated to intermolecular forces.error: Melting point IS related to intermolecular forces.
unrelated to intermolecular forces.fix: Melting = breaking molecules from fixed positions in solid. Stronger forces = more energy needed = higher m.p.
unrelated to intermolecular forces.action: Ice (H-bonding) melts at 0°C. Methane (dispersion only) melts at -182°C. Forces matter.

only depends on molecular shape.error: Shape matters but so does intermolecular force strength.
only depends on molecular shape.fix: Melting point depends on how well molecules pack in solid AND strength of forces between them.
only depends on molecular shape.action: Both packing efficiency (shape) and force strength affect melting point.

persistent.gap: You don't connect melting point to intermolecular forces like you do boiling point.
persistent.action: Remember: solid→liquid and liquid→gas both require overcoming intermolecular forces.

viscosity_definition.name: Viscosity Definition
viscosity_definition.formula: Resistance to flow; stronger IMF → higher viscosity
viscosity_definition.correct: Viscosity is a measure of a fluid's resistance to flow. Stronger intermolecular forces between molecules make it harder for them to slide past each other, increasing viscosity.

how fast a liquid flows.error: Viscosity is resistance TO flow, not flow rate itself.
how fast a liquid flows.fix: High viscosity = flows slowly (high resistance). Low viscosity = flows easily (low resistance).
how fast a liquid flows.action: Honey (high viscosity) flows slowly. Water (low viscosity) flows easily. Viscosity resists flow.

same as boiling point.error: Viscosity and boiling point are related but not the same property.
same as boiling point.fix: Both depend on intermolecular forces, but viscosity measures flow resistance in liquids; b.p. measures liquid→gas transition.
same as boiling point.action: A liquid at room temperature has both a viscosity AND a boiling point. Different measurements.

unrelated to intermolecular forces.error: Viscosity directly depends on intermolecular forces.
unrelated to intermolecular forces.fix: Stronger forces = molecules resist sliding past each other = higher viscosity.
unrelated to intermolecular forces.action: Glycerol (3 -OH groups, lots of H-bonding) is very viscous. Hexane (dispersion only) flows easily.

persistent.gap: You're not connecting viscosity to the molecular-level picture of forces between molecules.
persistent.action: Picture molecules sliding past each other. Strong forces = resist sliding = high viscosity.

viscosity_molar_mass.name: Viscosity and Molar Mass
viscosity_molar_mass.formula: Higher molar mass → stronger dispersion forces → higher viscosity
viscosity_molar_mass.correct: Within a homologous series, viscosity increases with molar mass because larger molecules have stronger dispersion forces, making them resist flowing past each other.

viscosity decreases with molar mass.error: Opposite. Larger molecules are MORE viscous.
viscosity decreases with molar mass.fix: More electrons = stronger dispersion forces = harder to slide past = higher viscosity.
viscosity decreases with molar mass.action: Compare alkanes: pentane (low viscosity) vs heavy oil fractions (very viscous). Size matters.

molar mass doesn't affect viscosity.error: Molar mass strongly affects viscosity within a homologous series.
molar mass doesn't affect viscosity.fix: Same type of forces, but larger molecules have MORE dispersion force contacts = higher viscosity.
molar mass doesn't affect viscosity.action: Measure flow rate of short-chain vs long-chain alkanes. Big difference.

only temperature affects viscosity.error: Both temperature AND molecular properties affect viscosity.
only temperature affects viscosity.fix: Temperature changes kinetic energy. Molar mass changes intermolecular force strength. Both matter.
only temperature affects viscosity.action: At same temperature, larger molecules are more viscous. Temperature is another factor.

persistent.gap: You don't understand how molecular size affects viscosity.
persistent.action: Think of long chains tangling vs short chains sliding easily. Length matters.

viscosity_temperature.name: Viscosity and Temperature
viscosity_temperature.formula: Higher temperature → higher kinetic energy → lower viscosity
viscosity_temperature.correct: Viscosity decreases as temperature increases because molecules have more kinetic energy to overcome intermolecular forces and flow more freely.

viscosity increases with temperature.fix: More kinetic energy = easier to overcome forces = easier to flow = lower viscosity.
viscosity increases with temperature.action: Cold honey is thick (high viscosity). Warm honey flows easily (low viscosity).

temperature doesn't affect viscosity.error: Temperature has a significant effect on viscosity.
temperature doesn't affect viscosity.fix: This is why we heat viscous liquids to make them flow more easily (warm oil, honey, etc.).
temperature doesn't affect viscosity.action: Try pouring cold vs warm honey. Temperature clearly affects viscosity.

only affects some liquids.error: Temperature affects viscosity of ALL liquids.
only affects some liquids.fix: The effect might be more noticeable in already-viscous liquids, but all liquids show this trend.
only affects some liquids.action: Even water's viscosity decreases with temperature (just harder to notice).

persistent.gap: You're not connecting kinetic energy to the ability of molecules to flow.
persistent.action: Think: more energy = more movement = easier to slide past neighbours = lower resistance = lower viscosity.

comparing_families.name: Comparing Physical Properties Between Families
comparing_families.formula: Different functional groups = different force types = different property trends
comparing_families.correct: Different homologous series have different functional groups, leading to different types of intermolecular forces and thus different ranges of physical properties for similar-sized molecules.

all organic families have same propertie.error: Different functional groups give very different physical properties.
all organic families have same propertie.fix: Alkanes (dispersion only) have very different b.p. than alcohols (H-bonding) of similar mass.
all organic families have same propertie.action: Compare ethane (b.p. -89°C) vs methanol (b.p. 65°C). Similar mass, very different b.p.

molecular formula determines properties.error: Functional group (structure) matters more than just the formula.
molecular formula determines properties.fix: Isomers with same formula can have different properties based on functional groups.
molecular formula determines properties.action: Ethanol and dimethyl ether (both C₂H₆O) have b.p. 78°C vs -24°C. Structure matters.

only alkanes can be compared.error: We can compare any organic families when controlling for molar mass.
only alkanes can be compared.fix: Compare similar-mass molecules from different families to see effect of functional group.
only alkanes can be compared.action: Compare ~60 g/mol: propane (-42°C), acetone (56°C), propan-1-ol (97°C). Same mass, different forces.

persistent.gap: You're not systematically comparing families by controlling molar mass.
persistent.action: Make a table: compare b.p. of similar-mass molecules from different families. Note force types.

intermolecular_forces.title: Intermolecular Forces in Organic Compounds
intermolecular_forces.instructions: Complete the statements about the types of intermolecular forces in organic molecules.

sentences.text: Dispersion forces exist between {{d1}} molecules and arise from temporary dipoles caused by the random movement of {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: Think about what causes dispersion forces. Do all molecules have this?

d2.tooltip: Which subatomic particles are mobile and cause temporary charge imbalances?

sentences.text: Within a homologous series, the strength of dispersion forces {{d3}} as molar mass increases because larger molecules have {{d4}} electrons.

d3.tooltip: What happens to force strength with more electrons?

d4.tooltip: Larger molecules have more atoms and therefore...

sentences.text: Hydrogen bonding occurs when hydrogen is bonded to {{d5}} and can interact with a lone pair on another electronegative atom. This force is {{d6}} than typical dipole-dipole interactions.

d5.tooltip: Which atoms are electronegative enough for H-bonding?

d6.tooltip: Rank: hydrogen bonding vs dipole-dipole vs dispersion.

sentences.text: Alcohols have {{d7}} boiling points than alkanes of similar molar mass because alcohols can form {{d8}}, while alkanes can only form dispersion forces.

d8.tooltip: What special intermolecular force can -OH groups form?

boiling_point.title: Boiling Point Trends
boiling_point.instructions: Complete the statements about how structure affects boiling point.

sentences.text: Boiling point is the temperature at which molecules have enough {{d1}} to overcome the {{d2}} forces holding them in the liquid state.

d1.tooltip: What type of energy relates to molecular motion?

d2.tooltip: Forces BETWEEN molecules, not within them.

sentences.text: Within a homologous series, boiling point {{d3}} as the number of carbon atoms increases because {{d4}} forces become stronger with larger molecular size.

d3.tooltip: More carbons means larger molecule means...

d4.tooltip: Which force increases with more electrons and surface area?

sentences.text: Branched isomers have {{d5}} boiling points than straight-chain isomers because branching {{d6}} the surface area available for intermolecular contact.

d5.tooltip: Less surface contact means weaker forces means...

d6.tooltip: Branched molecules are more spherical, touching less of neighbours.

sentences.text: Comparing molecules of similar molar mass, those with {{d7}} have the highest boiling points, followed by those with dipole-dipole interactions, and lowest for molecules with {{d8}} only.

d8.tooltip: Non-polar molecules have only which type of force?

melting_point.title: Melting Point Trends
melting_point.instructions: Complete the statements about melting point behaviour in organic compounds.

sentences.text: Melting is the transition from {{d1}} to {{d2}}, which requires overcoming the intermolecular forces holding molecules in fixed positions.
The melting point trend within a homologous series is generally {{d3}} to the boiling point trend, with both increasing as {{d4}} increases.

d3.tooltip: Both transitions involve overcoming the same forces.

d4.tooltip: What property of the molecule increases down a homologous series?

sentences.text: Compounds capable of hydrogen bonding typically have {{d5}} melting points than similar-sized molecules with only dispersion forces, because {{d6}} forces must be overcome.

d5.tooltip: Stronger forces need more energy to overcome.

d6.tooltip: H-bonding is stronger than dispersion alone.

viscosity.title: Viscosity Trends
viscosity.instructions: Complete the statements about viscosity in organic liquids.

sentences.text: Viscosity is defined as a fluid's resistance to {{d1}}. A fluid with high viscosity flows {{d2}} than one with low viscosity.

d1.tooltip: Viscosity measures how easily a liquid can...

d2.tooltip: High resistance to flow means flows...

sentences.text: Viscosity depends on the strength of {{d3}} forces. Stronger forces between molecules make it {{d4}} for them to slide past each other.

d3.tooltip: Forces between neighbouring molecules in the liquid.

sentences.text: Within a homologous series, viscosity {{d5}} as molar mass increases. As temperature increases, viscosity {{d6}} because molecules have more energy to overcome intermolecular forces.

d5.tooltip: Larger molecules have stronger dispersion forces.

d6.tooltip: More kinetic energy helps molecules flow more easily.

sentences.text: Glycerol is much more viscous than propan-1-ol despite similar molar mass because glycerol has {{d7}} hydroxyl groups, enabling {{d8}} hydrogen bonds per molecule.

d8.tooltip: More -OH groups can form more H-bonds.

intermolecular_forces.title: Applying Intermolecular Force Concepts
intermolecular_forces.instructions: Apply your understanding of intermolecular forces to these scenarios.

sentences.text: Aldehydes and ketones have {{d1}} boiling points than alcohols of similar molar mass because they can only form {{d2}} interactions, not hydrogen bonds between their own molecules.

d1.tooltip: Dipole-dipole is weaker than hydrogen bonding.

d2.tooltip: C=O is polar but H is not bonded to O, N, or F in aldehydes/ketones.

sentences.text: The strength of dispersion forces depends on the {{d3}} of the molecule, which relates to how many electrons are available to create {{d4}} dipoles.

d3.tooltip: What changes as you go down a homologous series?

d4.tooltip: Dispersion forces arise from instantaneous, not permanent, dipoles.

sentences.text: Carboxylic acids have exceptionally high boiling points because they can form {{d5}} between two molecules, creating strongly bonded pairs called {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: The -COOH group has both H-bond donor and acceptor sites.

d6.tooltip: Two molecules bonded together are called...

sentences.text: Molecules in the same homologous series have the same {{d7}}, so their physical property differences are mainly due to differences in {{d8}}.

d8.tooltip: Members differ by CH₂, which changes what property?

boiling_point.title: Boiling Point Applications
boiling_point.instructions: Apply boiling point concepts to compare different molecules.

sentences.text: Pentane has a boiling point of 36°C while 2,2-dimethylpropane boils at only 10°C. Despite having identical {{d1}}, the branched isomer has {{d2}} surface area for intermolecular contact.

d1.tooltip: Both are C₅H₁₂ but have different structures.

d2.tooltip: Spherical shape means less contact area.

sentences.text: Ethanol (C₂H₅OH) boils at 78°C while dimethyl ether (CH₃OCH₃) boils at -24°C. Both have identical molecular formulas, but only {{d3}} can form hydrogen bonds between its own molecules because {{d4}} is bonded directly to the oxygen.

d4.tooltip: For H-bonding, H must be bonded to F, N, or O.

sentences.text: When comparing propan-1-ol (b.p. 97°C) and propan-2-ol (b.p. 82°C), the {{d5}} isomer has the lower boiling point because the -OH group is {{d6}}, reducing the overall surface area for dispersion forces.

d5.tooltip: propan-2-ol has -OH on the middle carbon.

distractors: at the end of the chain

sentences.text: Octane (b.p. 126°C) has a higher boiling point than methanol (b.p. 65°C) even though methanol can form hydrogen bonds. This shows that {{d7}} can overcome the advantage of hydrogen bonding when comparing molecules of very {{d8}} sizes.

d7.tooltip: What force does a large non-polar molecule have?

d8.tooltip: Octane is much larger than methanol.

melting_point.title: Melting Point Applications
melting_point.instructions: Apply melting point concepts to real examples.

sentences.text: Ice has a relatively high melting point (0°C) compared to methane (-182°C) because water molecules form an extensive {{d1}} network that requires significant energy to {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: Water has O-H bonds that can form...

d2.tooltip: Melting breaks molecules free from fixed positions.

sentences.text: Saturated fatty acids have {{d3}} melting points than unsaturated fatty acids of similar chain length because the straight chains can {{d4}} together more effectively.

d3.tooltip: Better packing = stronger dispersion forces = harder to melt.

d4.tooltip: Straight chains line up better than kinked chains.

sentences.text: The general trend for melting point within a homologous series shows that {{d5}} members have higher melting points due to {{d6}} intermolecular forces.

d5.tooltip: Same trend as boiling point with molar mass.

d6.tooltip: Larger molecules have more electrons and stronger dispersion forces.

viscosity.title: Viscosity Applications
viscosity.instructions: Apply viscosity concepts to practical situations.

sentences.text: Motor oil becomes {{d1}} viscous when heated because the increased {{d2}} energy helps molecules overcome intermolecular forces more easily.

d1.tooltip: Heat makes liquids flow more easily.

d2.tooltip: Temperature is related to molecular motion energy.

sentences.text: Long-chain hydrocarbons in heavy crude oil are more viscous than short-chain hydrocarbons in petrol because the longer molecules have {{d3}} dispersion forces and can also become {{d4}} with each other.

d3.tooltip: More atoms = more electrons = stronger dispersion.

d4.tooltip: Long chains can wrap around each other like spaghetti.

sentences.text: Honey is more viscous than water primarily because honey contains long-chain {{d5}} that have multiple -OH groups capable of extensive {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: Honey is mostly glucose and fructose.

sentences.text: Biodiesel must have {{d7}} viscosity to flow through fuel lines easily. This is why biodiesel is made from {{d8}} rather than saturated fats, which would be too viscous at room temperature.

d7.tooltip: Fuel needs to flow through narrow pipes.

d8.tooltip: Unsaturated chains don't pack as well.

intermolecular_forces.title: Mastering Intermolecular Forces
intermolecular_forces.instructions: Demonstrate complete understanding of intermolecular forces in organic chemistry.

sentences.text: The reason dispersion forces increase with molar mass is that larger molecules have more {{d1}}, which can create stronger {{d2}} dipoles when their positions fluctuate.

d1.tooltip: What particles move to create temporary dipoles?

d2.tooltip: Dispersion forces arise from temporary, not fixed, charge separations.

sentences.text: Esters can act as hydrogen bond {{d3}} but not {{d4}}, which is why they have lower boiling points than alcohols of similar molar mass despite both being polar.

d3.tooltip: The C=O oxygen has lone pairs to accept H-bonds.

d4.tooltip: Esters have no O-H or N-H bonds to donate.

sentences.text: When ranking intermolecular force strength for similar-sized molecules: {{d5}} > {{d6}} > dispersion forces only, which directly correlates with the ranking of their boiling points.

d6.tooltip: Intermediate strength between H-bonding and dispersion only.

sentences.text: Primary amines can form hydrogen bonds because the nitrogen has a {{d7}} pair and the N-H bonds provide hydrogen {{d8}} for bonding.

d7.tooltip: Nitrogen in amines has unshared electrons.

d8.tooltip: H bonded to N can participate in H-bonding.

boiling_point.title: Boiling Point Mastery
boiling_point.instructions: Demonstrate complete understanding of boiling point trends.

sentences.text: The difference in boiling point between ethanol (78°C) and ethane (-89°C) is approximately {{d1}}°C, demonstrating the dramatic effect of {{d2}} on physical properties.

d2.tooltip: Ethanol has -OH; ethane has only C-H bonds.

sentences.text: For structural isomers, the one with the {{d3}} surface area will have the {{d4}} boiling point because it maximises dispersion force interactions.

d3.tooltip: More surface contact = stronger dispersion forces.

d4.tooltip: Stronger forces need more energy to overcome.

sentences.text: Propanoic acid (b.p. 141°C) has a much higher boiling point than propan-1-ol (b.p. 97°C) despite similar molar masses because carboxylic acids form {{d5}} through double hydrogen bonding, effectively {{d6}} their molecular mass.

d6.tooltip: Two molecules acting as one larger unit.

sentences.text: Within the alkane homologous series, each additional CH₂ unit increases the boiling point by approximately {{d7}}°C because it adds {{d8}} electrons to participate in dispersion forces.

d7.tooltip: Check the b.p. difference between consecutive alkanes.

d8.tooltip: CH₂ has 8 more electrons (6 from C, 2 from H atoms).

melting_point.title: Melting Point Mastery
melting_point.instructions: Demonstrate complete understanding of melting point concepts.

sentences.text: Unlike boiling point trends which are very consistent, melting point trends can show {{d1}} patterns because melting also depends on how efficiently molecules can {{d2}} in the solid state.

d1.tooltip: Packing efficiency varies with molecular shape.

d2.tooltip: Solids have ordered arrangements of molecules.

sentences.text: Trans fatty acids have {{d3}} melting points than cis fatty acids because the trans configuration allows chains to {{d4}} more closely together.

d4.tooltip: Straight chains pack better than kinked chains.

sentences.text: The reason butter (saturated fat) is solid at room temperature while olive oil (unsaturated) is liquid relates to the {{d5}} of their carbon chains and resulting differences in {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: Saturated = straight, unsaturated = kinked at double bonds.

viscosity.title: Viscosity Mastery
viscosity.instructions: Demonstrate complete understanding of viscosity concepts.

sentences.text: Engine oils are designed with specific viscosity ranges because oil that is too {{d1}} at low temperatures won't flow to engine parts, while oil that is too {{d2}} at high temperatures won't provide adequate lubrication.

d1.tooltip: Cold oil needs to still be able to flow.

d2.tooltip: Hot oil still needs enough thickness to lubricate.

sentences.text: The viscosity of a liquid decreases with increasing temperature because the ratio of {{d3}} energy to {{d4}} force strength increases, allowing molecules to move past each other more easily.

d3.tooltip: Temperature relates to molecular motion energy.

d4.tooltip: The forces that resist flow between molecules.

sentences.text: Comparing ethane-1,2-diol (ethylene glycol) to ethanol, the diol is {{d5}} viscous because it has {{d6}} hydroxyl groups that can participate in hydrogen bonding.

d5.tooltip: More H-bonding capacity = more resistance to flow.

sentences.text: The pitch drop experiment demonstrates that even substances appearing solid can be extremely viscous {{d7}}, with pitch taking approximately {{d8}} years between drops at room temperature.

d8.tooltip: The famous experiment shows drops falling very slowly.
